A‘这是什么？’HI Sutton在他的Covert Shores网站上获得了来自FishMonster的Facebook视频，视频显示上周在佛罗里达州基韦斯特附近发现了一辆奇怪的车辆。实际上，它水面上唯一的部分是一个支撑天线阵列的桅杆。这辆车几乎可以肯定是美国Liquid Robotics公司(现在归波音公司BA﻿所有)制造的波浪滑翔机，这些天线表明它是美国海军一个名为传感器托管自主遥控飞机(SHARC)项目的一部分。
这个物体起初看起来像碎片-但它是在自己的力量下移动的。波浪滑翔机利用自然能量为持续数周、数月或数年的任务提供动力，无需加油。表面有一个“浮子”，就像一个10英尺长的冲浪板，上面覆盖着太阳能电池，驱动着它的电子设备。它通过系绳连接到30英尺以下的水下“潜艇”单元。随着海浪将冲浪板上下移动，铰接式潜水器会将上下运动转化为向前运动(这里的视频演示了这一动作)。典型的速度只有1-3节，但波浪滑翔机可以无限期地前进；2013年，滑翔机进行了一次史诗般的8000英里(约合1800公里)、长达一年的横渡太平洋之旅。
尽管它们已经被用于科学研究，但它们的长期耐力和低调使波浪滑翔机成为军事情报收集的理想选择，这可能是波音在2016年收购Maker Liquid Robotics的原因。多年来，美国海军一直在与波浪滑翔机合作，对它们狩猎潜艇的潜力表现出了兴趣。波浪滑翔机可以长时间游荡，拖着水下声纳阵列，进行通信和联系，将飞机或船只引导到目标上。一支低成本的波浪滑翔机舰队可以缓慢地扫过感兴趣的区域，覆盖的区域比几艘昂贵的载人船大得多。
海军的潜猎浪滑翔机被称为传感器托管自主研究飞船，简称SHARC。2011年，海军开始为他们的实验SHARC滑翔机配备“拖曳阵列集成”(Tail)，这是一种被动拖曳声阵。这是一套专门的灵敏水听器，它利用滑翔机安静的推进能力来接收远处的船用发动机。(它还提供了首字母缩写SHARC Tail)。
从那时起，海军的波浪滑翔机计划变得更加雄心勃勃。目前的研发预算文件显示，2019年和2020年的研发支出为每年600万美元，2021年翻了一番，2022年随着项目完成而逐渐减少。SHARC现在是使用自主无人驾驶系统收集信息的更广泛努力的一部分。SHARC的特殊角色是：
“为舰队提供低成本、不对称的优势，以支持多种机密任务。这包括对潜艇或相关潜艇活动的持续、自主的态势感知和预警，以潜在地支持TASWO/陷阱(即反潜艇行动)，以及广泛、秘密地实施能力，以加强战场(IPB)和打击任务的情报准备。“。(我强调)。
与水面舰艇相比，波浪滑翔机在声音上是无声的，视觉和雷达信号都很低，是隐身的。与潜艇不同的是，它们不断地将数据反馈给远程操作员。
目前的计划要求一支由20名海军SHARC组成的舰队在2021年执行一项全面的示范任务，作为一个合作的蜂群一起工作，收集信息。确切地说哪些信息是机密的。预算项目计划提到“机密有效载荷通过信号和图像数据的同时宽带数据链路执行关键情报、监视和侦察(ISR)任务”。此外，SHARCS可能正在收集信号情报、窃听通信和检测雷达发射-因此需要所有这些天线-但他们可能做的更多。
然而，美国并不是唯一拥有这项技术的国家。早在2016年，我就注意到俄罗斯海军正在测试一款几乎一模一样的名为Fugu的波浪滑翔机。尽管如此，尽管它最有可能是我们的设备，但在基韦斯特15英里外看到的设备可能只是他们的设备之一。这将不是第一次使用无人驾驶水艇进行间谍活动。

A ‘ what is this?’ Facebook video from FishMonster, picked up by HI Sutton on his  Covert Shores site, shows a curious vehicle spotted off Florida’s Key West last week. Virtually the only part of it above water is a mast supporting an array of antennae.  The vehicle is almost certainly a  Wave Glider made by U.S. company  Liquid Robotics (now owned by Boeing    BA﻿ ) , and the antennas suggest it is part of a U.S. Navy program known as Sensor Hosting Autonomous Remote Craft, or SHARC.
    The object at first looked like debris — but it is moving under its own power. The Wave Glider harnesses natural energy to power missions lasting weeks, months, or years without refueling. On the surface is a ‘float’ like a 10-foot-long surfboard covered in solar cells driving its electronics. This is connected via a tether to an underwater ‘sub’  unit 30 feet below. As waves move the surfboard up and down, the articulated sub converts up-and-down into forward motion (video demonstrating  the action here). Typical speed is just 1 - 3 knots, but the Wave Glider can keep going indefinitely; in 2013, one made an epic 8,000-mile,  year-long journey across the Pacific.
       Although they have been used for scientific research, their long endurance and low profile make Wave Gliders ideal for military intelligence gathering, which is likely why  Boeing bought makers Liquid Robotics in 2016. The U.S. Navy has been working with Wave Gliders for many years, showing interest in their  potential for hunting submarines. A Wave Glider can loiter for extended periods, towing an underwater sonar array and communicating and contacts to direct aircraft or ships on to a target. A fleet of low-cost Wave Gliders could sweep slowly across an area of interest, covering a much wider area than a few expensive manned ships.
  The Navy's sub-hunting Wave Glider is known as Sensor Hosting Autonomous Research Craft, or SHARC. In 2011 the Navy  started equipping their experimental SHARC gliders with the ‘Towed Array Integrated "L"  (TAIL),’ a passive towed acoustic array. This is a set of specialized sensitive hydrophones which take advantage of the glider’s quiet propulsion to pick up distant marine engines. (It also gives the acronym SHARC TAIL).
    Since then the Navy’s Wave Glider plans have grown more ambitious.  Current R&D budget documents show spending of $6 million a year in 2019 and 2020, doubling in 2021 and tailing off with project completion in 2022. SHARC is now part of a wider effort to use autonomous unmanned systems to gather information. SHARC’s particular role is to:
  “provide the fleet with a low cost, asymmetric advantage in support of  multiple classified missions. This includes persistent, autonomous situational awareness and  early warning of submarines or related submarine activity in potential support of TASWO/TRAPS [i.e. Anti-Submarine operations] as well as broad area,  clandestine implementation of capabilities that enhance Intelligence Preparation of the Battlefield (IPB) and strike missions.” (My emphasis).
  Wave Gliders, being  acoustically silent and with a low visual and radar signature are stealthy compared to surface vessels. Unlike submarines they continuously feed data back to remote operators.
  Current plans call for a fleet of 20 Navy SHARCS to carry out a full-scale demonstration mission in 2021, working together as a co-operative swarm to gather information. Exactly what information is classified. The  budget project plan mentions “classified payloads conducting critical Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) missions with simultaneous, wideband data links for signal and imagery data.“  The SHARCS may be gathering signals intelligence, eavesdropping on communications and detecting radar emissions – hence the need for all those antennae —but they may be doing much more.
  However, the U.S. is not the only one with this technology. Back in 2016 I noted a  near-identical copy of the Wave Glider called Fugu being tested by the Russian Navy. So, while it is most likely one of ours, the device seen 15 miles off Key West might just be one of theirs. It would not be the first  time unmanned water craft were used for spying.
  Update Tues 30th June: Thanks to some sharp-eyed readers, we now know  what those mysterious antennae are and what they tell us about the glider's mission off Florida.

A few weeks ago, we took a look at  the most aerodynamically efficient vehicles ever made. At the time, the lowest-drag production car for sale in the US was the Porsche Taycan, which cuts through the air with a drag coefficient (Cd) of 0.22. But the rather excellent electric Porsche won't wear that crown for very long.  Lucid Motors is readying production of its first battery electric vehicle, the Air, and it has just released the results of some wind tunnel testing. Tests at the Windshear facility in North Carolina have determined that the Air has a Cd of only 0.21.
 Moving through the air as easily as possible is important if you want to travel the farthest distance using a given amount of energy. As such, optimizing a car for low drag has become more important, first as regulators in Europe demanded more efficient cars, then more recently as range has become the most important attribute of a battery electric vehicle.
 "Aerodynamic efficiency plays a key role in achieving world-beating range and performance and is particularly valuable to an EV in that it provides 'smart range' independent of battery pack size. So naturally we intensively focused upon aerodynamics throughout the Lucid Air’s development. Our aero team worked seamlessly with design and engineering counterparts, establishing aero efficiency as a core tenet of Lucid Air from its very inception, enabling us to achieve this new standard," said Peter Rawlinson, CEO and CTO of Lucid Motors.
  Cutting drag was also a main concern for race car designers, back  before they discovered that other aerodynamic property called downforce. Ultra-low drag streamliners were most common at Le Mans, where a three-mile (4.8km) straight allowed for some extremely high top speeds. Similarly, the Lucid Air's top speed benefits from its low drag; one of the alpha prototypes has already bettered 235mph (378km/h) in testing, and Rawlinson told me recently that he's sure the car has more to show, although production cars will have an artificially limited Vmax to meet the safety rating of their tires.
 Lucid says its beta prototypes are regularly achieving over 400 miles (643km) of highway range in testing, and a real-world range of 400 miles is the company's target for the Air, which goes into production later this year. Currently, the only BEV with such long legs is the Tesla Model S,  which recently broke through that psychological barrier thanks to a process of incremental improvement over the past eight years.
 However, when the production Air is revealed to the world in September, it won't be the lowest-drag production car ever. That honor is held by a pair of streamliners that could only briefly be found in showrooms: the General Motors EV1 and the Volkswagen XL1.

Welcome to the pilot episode of "Human Interface," a new series we're kicking off wherein we take you up close and personal with complex systems and have an expert explain what all the buttons and switches do. "Pilot episode" is particularly appropriate here, because we're kicking off the series with a look at a McDonnell Douglas F-15C Eagle, one of the world's most famous air superiority fighters. The F-15C and its variants are in service with multiple air forces around the world, including the United States, Japan, and Israel, and the aircraft has an outstanding combat record—across all its deployments and operators, air-superiority F-15s like the F-15C have racked up more than 100 air-to-air kills and zero losses.
 Before the coronavirus made everything crazy, we were able to score some time with an F-15C on the flight line at Fresno Air National Guard Base in California. Our tour guide was Air Force pilot  Colonel Andrea Themely, who  retired in 2018 after serving for 23 years. Col. Themely has about 3,400 hours piloting high-performance jet fighters and about 1,100 hours specifically in F-15Cs, and her last post was commanding the Air Force's  80th Flying Training Wing.
  As I found out firsthand a few years ago in  the Navy's F/A-18 simulator at NAS Oceana, a  fourth-generation jet fighter like the F-15C is typically equipped with a mish-mash of '70s- and '80s-era screens and buttons, with other more current-looking '00s-era controls shoehorned into the corners. This reflects the fact that fighters like the F-15C and its contemporaries are mostly products of the 1970s, with more modern improvements bolted on over time.
 Our California ANG F-15C is no exception, and Col. Themely spends a lot of the video explaining the physical controls in the cockpit—switches and levers that actuate functions that on a more modern  fifth-generation fighter might instead be primarily  accessed via touchscreen.
 The amount of controls to address might appear overwhelming, but there's a secret to aircraft cockpits—you tend to only care about a few things at any given moment, so once you're familiar with the instruments, you focus on what you need and ignore the rest. It's the exact same thing people do when driving a car or operating any complex piece of machinery.
  We're really excited about the possibilities of "Human Interface" as a series, and we have  many more cool machines we'd like to see explained like this. Airliners, submarines,  huge earth moving machines, power plants,  giant car-eating dinosaur monster trucks—we've got a long list of stuff we're trying to get in to see, and if you have any suggestions, please feel free to leave them in the comments.
 My personal bucket list item for the series would be to have some Apollo-era flight controllers walk us through  NASA's restored Mission Operations Control Room 2 in Houston, but since its multi-million dollar restoration, NASA has been reticent to allow any filming on the floor of MOCR2. We'll definitely keep asking!

The politeness transfer engine that the CMU research team (including Language Technology Institutes Ph.D student Shrimai Prabhumoye, as well as Master’s students Aman Madaan, Amrith Setlur and Tanmay Parekh) developed is based on similar style transfer mechanisms you may be more familiar with from photography  AI   projects, where software can apply the style of one photograph to any other. This project used a dataset of half a million emails exchanged by Enron employees, which were made public as part of legal proceedings against the company resulting from its corruption and fraud scandals.
 Despite the company’s wrongdoing, many of the emails exchanged between employees were – unsurprisingly, if you’ve ever worked in a large corporation – laden with common niceties and politely formed requests and responses. These proved a good basis form which to train a computational linguistics algorithm that could then be used to take either basic or impolite requests, like ‘Show me last month’s reports,’ and turn that into something with a little more basic human kindness and decency, like ‘Could you please send me the reports from last month?’
  It might seem like the task is relatively simple – append a ‘please’ and ‘thank you’ to any phase and you’re mostly there, right? In fact, the researchers say that it actually involved a lot more subtlety, since in fact when we are striving to be polite we do a lot more, like rephrase what’s actually an order to be a request, as in the example above.
 The automated method that the CMU team developed works only in North American English, as employed in a formal (ie. workplace) setting for now, and there will be lots of work required in order to localize it since regional and linguistic differences regarding what’s considered polite vary greatly. But even in its current form, it could provide a lot of benefit when used for automated customer service chatbots, for instance, or in autosuggesting text in an email client.
 There’s clearly an interest in this from companies who make significant use of automated text suggestions – like Apple, which provided support for this research alongside the Air Force Research Laboratory, the Office of Naval Research, the National Science Foundation and NVIDIA.

总部设在伦敦和纽约的风险投资集团(Venture Collective)今天成立，目的是让获得资本变得更加平等。公平警告：它的实验结构很复杂，因为TVC既是部分投资工具，也是部分管理公司。但在一个科技难以取得进展的应得领域，这是一种创造性的战略。
这个团队经验丰富：创始合伙人尼克·谢克德米安(Nick Shekerdemian)曾是YC初创公司的创始人，推出了一个多元化招聘平台，他的联合创始人吉娜·基尔奇(Gina Kirch)是他的投资者之一，也是贝莱德(BlackRock)的前董事。其他合伙人包括前Primary Venture Partners投资者凯特·赫尔南德斯(Cat Hernandez)和埃利奥特·里士满(Elliot Richmond)，他们在英国以外的地区投资，之前曾在莫里斯公司(Moelis&Amp；Company)工作。
对于初创企业，企业每月将向一家公司投资10万美元，并可以灵活地做更多事情。TVC打算为后续几轮预留100万至500万美元。
对于家族理财室，TVC收取年费，作为他们认为在硅谷有利可图的种子前交易的情报。如果家族理财室或其网络中的某人想要投资，TVC最终会部署一定数量的资本。它希望总资本承诺将随着时间的推移而增加。
尽管TVC表示，这种结构模式是隐形的，但将这些家族理财室投资的结构与特殊目的载体的结构进行比较是合理的。特殊目的公司是存在于基金资本分配之外的投资工具，与传统的辛迪加相比，它们更具冲动。
最大的区别是SPV的结构是以交易为中心的，而TVC的结构是以资本分配为中心，部署到多个交易中。他们基本上充当了有前途的初创公司和家族理财室之间的中间人。
这对家族理财室来说是个好消息，因为他们经常扮演机构投资者的角色，这是长达十年的合作关系。长期押注的问题是，2010年热门的东西在2020年可能不会热门。TVC的模式让有限责任公司每年在自己感兴趣的领域配置资本。因此，新近看好远程工作的LP(出于某种疯狂的原因)可以参与早期交易，而不是等待他们几年前投资的AR/VR基金采取这一行动。
由于所有这些机制，TVC的总“基金规模”将根据周的不同而变化。这是一个独特的例子，说明了首次投资的基金经理是如何在动荡的环境中进行投资的。
今天，TVC推出了基于股权的融资，数额不详。该公司拒绝分享管理下的总资产。
因此，TVC成功的一个重要因素是它是否能让创始人和家族理财室都相信，它的观点是值得建立的。TVC的灵活性可能是一件好事，但如果家族理财室退出，它也可能存在风险和不可靠。或者，例如，如果出现了长期的衰退。
作为一种甜头，该公司表示，它将捐赠三分之二的合作伙伴时间来帮助投资组合中的公司。
但是，这如何适应多样性呢？这一切都回到了TVC的目标，即让获得资本的机会更加平等。
根据该团队的说法，大多数公司都失败了，但支持A系列的预种子基金也是资源最紧张的(基金规模较小，管理费固定)。因此，公司必须有选择地选择他们认为是离群点的公司，并更定期地花时间与这些公司打交道。这对代表不足的创始人的影响不成比例，他们可能会因为无法获得资源而起步较慢。
TVC认为，它的战略将通过在这段时间内大力支持初创公司，帮助增加可风险投资的初创公司的数量，而不会竞争和抬高只有几个离群点的估值。
该公司通过多样性、地理位置、年龄和社会背景来定义代表性不足的创始人。当被问及是否会公开披露多样性指标时，TVC表示，“它希望深思熟虑地考虑如何让我们的投资在长期内承担责任，我们正在权衡这一点与不作规定的愿望。”
我们认为，作为早期投资者，我们的部分工作是确保随着业务规模的扩大，这一意图是最重要的。这可以有多种形式--跟踪/报告多样性指标就是其中之一。本质上，这不是装点门面，“该公司告诉TechCrunch。一般说来，TVC专注于帮助更多的人获得资金，并指出财务选择权是“我们正在争取的飞轮”。
在采购方面，TVC正在与纽约和伦敦的专注于科技的团体合作，并将在大学和学院层面寻找人才。该公司还表示，将与“最著名的科技公司”代表不足的运营商建立关系，并与专注于多元化的创始人共同投资。
TVC还推出了一个名为“The Collective”的团体，其中包括不同的创始人、运营商和投资者，他们将作为交易流动渠道提供帮助。
note_en:
So, Hernandez has teamed up with a number of operators-turned-investors to tackle tech’s diversity problem from a creative angle.
  The Venture Collective, based in London and New York, launches today to make access to capital more equal. Fair warning: its experimental structure is knotty, as TVC is part investment vehicle and part management company. But it’s a creative strategy in a deserving sector that tech struggles to make progress within.
 The team is stacked with a variety of experience: Founding partner Nick Shekerdemian is a former YC startup founder who launched a diversity recruitment platform, and his co-founder, Gina Kirch, was one of his investors, as well as a former director at BlackRock. Other partners include former  Primary Venture Partners   investor Cat Hernandez and Elliot Richmond, who invests out of the United Kingdom and previously worked at Moelis & Company.
   For startups, the business will invest a $100,000 check into one company per month, with the flexibility to do more. TVC intends to reserve between $1 to $5 million for follow-on rounds.
 For family offices, TVC charges an annual fee to serve as intel for what they think are lucrative pre-seed deals in the Valley. If a family office or someone within its network wants to invest, TVC  will ultimately deploy an allocated amount of capital. It hopes that total capital commitments will increase over time.
 While TVC says the structure model is in stealth, it is reasonable to compare the structures of these family office investments to the structures of  special purpose vehicles. SPVs are investment vehicles that exist outside a fund’s capital allotment and are more spur of the moment, versus traditionally syndicated.
 The biggest difference is that SPV structure is centered around deals, but TVC’s structure is centered around a capital allotment, deployed into multiple deals. They essentially act as middlemen between promising startups and family offices.
 It’s good news for family offices, as they often take the role of institutional investors, which are decade-long relationships. The problem with lengthy bets is that what was hot in 2010 might not be hot in 2020. TVC’s model lets LPs deploy capital in their interest areas on a year by year basis. So an LP who is newly bullish on remote work (for some wild reason) could get their hands in early deals instead of waiting for the AR/VR fund they invested in years ago to make that move.
   Because of all of these mechanisms, TVC’s total “fund size” will change depending on the week. It’s a unique example of how first-time fund managers are  tackling investing in a volatile landscape.
 Today TVC launches with an undisclosed amount of equity-based financing. The company declined to share total assets under management.
 So a big factor in TVC’s success is if it can convince both founders and family offices that its perspective is worth the set up. TVC’s flexibility can be a blessing, but it also can be risky and unreliable in case family offices pull out. Or if there is an extended recession, for example.
 As a sweetener, the company says that it will donate two-thirds of partner time to helping portfolio companies.
 But how does this fit into diversity? It all goes back to TVC’s goal to make access to capital more equal.
 According to the team, pre-seed to Series A is where most companies fail, but the very funds that back pre-seed are also the most strapped for resources (small fund sizes, fixed management fees). Thus, firms have to selectively pick the companies they think are outliers and spend time with those companies on a more regular basis. This disproportionately impacts underrepresented founders, who might have a slower start due to lack of access to resources.
 TVC thinks its strategy will help grow the number of startups that are venture-backable by heavily supporting them through this time, without competing and driving up valuations for only a few outliers.
 The company defined underrepresented founders through diversity, geography, age and social background. When asked if they will publicly disclose diversity metrics, TVC said “it wants to be thoughtful about how we hold our investments accountable in the long-term and we are balancing that with a desire to not be prescriptive.”
 “We believe that part of our job as early investors is to ensure that this intent is top of mind as the business scales. That can come in many forms — tracking/reporting on diversity metrics being one of them. At its core, this isn’t about window dressing,” the firm told TechCrunch. Generally, TVC is focused on helping more people get funding, and pointed toward financial optionality as the “flywheel we’re playing for.”
 In terms of sourcing, TVC is partnering with tech-focused groups in New York and London and will identify talent at the university and college level. It also said it will build relationships with underrepresented operators “at the most prominent tech companies” and co-invest with diversity-focused founders.
 TVC also launched a group called “The Collective” that includes diverse founders, operators and investors, who will help as a deal flow channel.
title: Venture Collective启动对种子前期投资的新押注
title_en: The Venture Collective launches with a new bet on pre-seed investing

That’s  the warning from US Cyber Command, a division of the Dept. of Defense and former sister-agency to the NSA, which said enterprises should patch their vulnerable devices as soon as possible.
 Please patch all devices affected by CVE-2020-2021 immediately, especially if SAML is in use. Foreign APTs will likely attempt exploit soon. We appreciate  @PaloAltoNtwks’ proactive response to this vulnerability.
 The flaw lies in the software that powers several Palo Alto Networks firewalls and enterprise VPN appliances, which let employees access their corporate network from home — access that is crucial during the pandemic — while keeping unauthorized users out.
 Typically employees must enter their corporate username and password, and often a two-factor code. But the flaw could, under certain conditions, let an attacker take control of one of these devices without needing a password, granting them access to the rest of the network.
 Palo Alto said  that a fix was pushed out in a software update, but enterprises can also switch off SAML — a way of letting a user log in to the network — to mitigate the flaw.
 But the clock is ticking on enterprises getting those fixes installed. VPN appliances and firewalls are a huge target for hackers as they can provide unfettered access to a corporate network.
 Last year, researchers  found flaws in three corporate VPN appliances — including Palo Alto. Although fixes were quickly rolled out, enterprises that were slow to patch found their networks under attack, prompting Homeland Security’s cyber advisory unit to issue an alert.  In some cases, hackers used the vulnerability to  spread ransomware  across the network.
 For the time being, Palo Alto says there’s no evidence yet of hackers exploiting this vulnerability. But given the immediate risk to networks, companies should patch as soon as possible.

Based on a 12nm process technology, these new platforms promise to breathe new life into the Android Wear ecosystem.
 One of the first things users will notice is that, compared to the previous generation of Wear 3100 chips, the 4100+ platform will offer support for a far richer ambient mode, which can now show more colors in this energy-efficient mode all while supporting sleep tracking, live complications and adaptive brightness.
  Traditionally, in the Android Wear ecosystem, the ambient mode was quite pared down compared to the live mode, but this new platform is going to change that. According to Qualcomm’s data, most smartwatches spent 95% of their time in ambient mode, so that was an obvious feature to improve upon. For its sports mode, the watch falls back to a similar mode, which now features similar capabilities to keep you up to date while you are on a run, for example, and are using various sensors, maps and the GPS.

Step counting, heart rate monitoring and more is handled by a tiny always-on co-processor, (it measures 5mmx4mm), while a 4G modem provides high-speed connectivity.

 The first watches to use the new 4100 chips will come from Mobvoi, the makers of the TicWatch line, and imoo, which will launch a kid-centric smartwatch based on the platform.

大约十年前，我有机会在厄瓜多尔的基多住了不到一年。我认为，每一个想要建设更具生产力的地方的北美人，都可以作为一名居民，而不仅仅是一名游客，从体验全球南方的城市中受益。虽然这些地方在城市形态、建筑和文化上有巨大的差异，但也有一些重要的共同点。一个很大的问题是，日常生活和商业的基础设施比我们在美国习惯的正式秩序和标准化要少得多。事情只是变得更混乱了。
在居住在厄瓜多尔之前，我被误导相信，那里的事情不会像在这里那样好。另一方面，我离开了厄瓜多尔，感觉有一些教训美国应该好好考虑一下。秩序和效率并不总是如人们所说的那样。让我通过一个故事来解释一下，我在基多布置公寓家具的那一天，与美国的相同过程相比。
我和我的室友在一套令人惊叹的殖民地式复式公寓里租了楼上的公寓，公寓铺着硬木地板，有充足的自然光，当然，如果不是因为价格标签，这在加州是不会显得格格不入的。年迈的女房东独自带着她的三条狗住在楼下。这个地方完全没有家具，所以我们在一个星期六出发，去买下一年我们需要的东西，把它称为家。
这意味着，首先，要跳上一辆公交车。基多有BRT(快速公交)系统(现在正在建设一条地铁)，但它的三条BRT线路极其拥挤，沿着城市的南北轴线运行，使得东西走向变得更加困难。
幸运的是，有大量的非正式公共交通：由私营运营商运营的大型蓝色公交车将穿梭在每条主干道上，在前挡风玻璃上挂着一大堆标志-多达12个-列出了主要目的地：社区、大学和其他地标。没有路线图，没有提前时间表-但只要对这座城市有一点基本的地理知识，我发现你可以可靠地从任何地方跳到任何地方，只需25到50美分，而且在车站的等待时间不超过5分钟。
在乘坐公共交通出行的便利性方面，几乎没有一个美国城市能与基多竞争-我被告知基多将是一个贫穷和功能失调的地方。这些非正式公交线路的网络并没有从上面得到协调：我花了一个小时在谷歌上搜索，才明白在一个地方没有总时刻表和系统图。这个系统虽然混乱，但却很聪明：如果有出行需求(在A点和B点之间的公交车上人满为患)，就会有人找出问题所在，并加以利用。这个系统缺乏易读性的地方-我确实喜欢在离家前在网上钻研交通线路图和计划我的旅行-它获得了快速、迭代的适应性。
我们去了一个由几个街区组成的小镇，那里有很多家具店。每一家单独的商店都很小，有有限的、独特的选择。但由于他们中的六个人离得很近，很容易漫步和比较商店。不到一个小时左右，我们就有了一套我们喜欢的餐厅用具，几盏灯和一张沙发。我们从一个巨大的露天市场从个别小贩那里买来的二手炉子和冰箱，在那里你几乎可以买到任何东西。在这两种情况下，我们都坚持让他们为我们插上电源，然后我们在一小时后回来验证它是否正常工作。讨价还价，交了定金，就该找交通工具了。
运输车由两个人组成，开着一辆没有标志的卡车。梅尔卡多酒店外的一整条街似乎都在非正式地为这些卡车服务：只要找个人停着等着，让他们知道他们要拖的是什么，如果你想让他们帮你把卡车搬上楼梯进入公寓(我们做到了)，还可以多付一点钱。几个小时后，我们少了几百美元，在用绳子锁着的冰箱旁边的皮卡车床上经历了一次令人焦虑的旅行后，我们回到了家，家具几乎齐全。
我们很喜欢家具，尽管烤箱很快就坏了，需要通过口口相传的方式找到一名维修员，他可以找到合适的更换部件。同时，我还学会了在炉子上做很多意想不到的东西！这是个不错的煤气炉，由一大罐独立的丙烷(你可以用一辆卡车运送，每周有几个早上在附近巡逻)。
整个经历与我在美国布置家具的经历形成了鲜明对比。在这里，这个过程总是涉及开车去大卖场(其中很少有交通工具很方便，特别是如果你需要多次停留的话)，信用检查，一些承诺几个月付款计划的文书工作，一到两周的预定送货时间，以及经常与快递公司发生一些麻烦，要求打一个电话，我坐在那里等待。
因为那个麻烦，我得到了更大程度的保护，以防事情出错。去年，当一台洗碗机来到我家时，旁边已经有一个很大的凹痕，我一点钱都没有花；他们把它拿走，道歉，退还了送货费，并允许我在一周后重新安排更换设备。几年前，我们买了一张沙发，在送货时发现，它不可能通过我们后院Adu的一个棘手的门口(异常狭窄，只有29英寸，但也是一个90°的小转弯)。没问题：把沙发放回去，又去挑了一张。
你会认为选择范围更广会是美国体制的一项福利，但对我们来说并非如此：大包厢里的选择是重复的，而且受到当前市场趋势的严重影响。所有房间里都没有一张沙发小到可以转弯，穿过门进入我们的起居室。当我对售货员说这番话时，她嘲弄地告诉我应该考虑大一点的房子。(真实故事！)。我们离开，在这条路上的另一家大卖场买了一张沙发。两周后如期交付。
我很清楚，美国中产阶级做事的方式--家得宝/宜家/Roomers to Go模式--有其优势，特别是在降低买家上当受骗、没有追索权的风险方面。但值得深思的是，这些商店承诺的质量和可靠性的隐性成本。
最大的此类成本是生产商、零售商和消费者的进入门槛都要高得多。在美国，你找不到很多卖家具和电器的小店主；在基多这样的城市里，这种做法很管用，因为这是一个露天市场的物理模型，那里有许多小的零售空间，彼此步行很近。(当然，现在有小商家的在线选择，比如Craigslist、Facebook Marketplace等，但这种模式也有很大的缺点，因为你真的希望在购买之前能够触摸和测试一些东西。)。大卖场对市场的垄断也将规模较小的手工生产商拒之门外。对于购物者来说，成为一个快乐的消费者，而没有几个小时的额外麻烦，恼人的运输物流，以及不确定性，其代价往往是债务，形式是汽车付款和信用卡。
在基多布置房子的经历真的、真的让人释放了一些东西，因为两个外国人的西班牙语水平不太好，没有当地的银行账户，也没有当地接受的信用卡，而且对这个城市相当不熟悉。我们在一个下午能完成的工作量是惊人的。选择的范围实际上相当不错。四处走动是轻而易举的事。
美国的体系-拥有垂直整合的供应链、仓库和航运网络、专有信贷额度的大卖场-对一群特定的人来说是有效的：资本所有者。也就是说，高管和股东。这种零售模式通过从供应链的每个部分榨取每一点冗余，在从顶部榨取利润方面几乎是最有效的。
从CEO(或城市管理者)的角度来看，美国的发展模式也符合这种特定的效率模式。分开的土地用途；有巨大停车场的大型购物广场；为18轮车建造的步行街；以及指定的走廊上只允许交通：所有这些都有利于大盒子模式的商业。
对于其他所有人来说，我认为有一个强有力的论点，那就是我们在自上而下的秩序和效率方向上走得太远了，回到一个混乱的城市和充斥着小企业主的混乱市场--我听说过拥有更多资本家的资本主义--将产生令人惊讶的好处。我只是要去南美看看他们中的几个。

About a decade ago, I had the opportunity to live in Quito, Ecuador for a little under a year. I think every North American who wants to build more productive places can benefit from experiencing a city of the Global South as a resident, not just a tourist. While there's an enormous amount of variation among these places in urban form, architecture, and culture, there are some important commonalities too. One big one is that the infrastructure of day-to-day life and commerce exhibits a lot less of the formal order and standardization we're used to encountering in the United States. Things are just  messier.
 I was led to believe, before living in Ecuador, that Things Just Don't Work as Well There As They Do Here. I left Ecuador, on the other hand, feeling like there are some lessons the United States would do well to consider. Order and efficiency aren't always all they're cracked up to be. Let me explain via a story about the day I furnished my apartment in Quito, in comparison to the same process in the States.
  My housemate and I had rented the upstairs apartment in a stunning old colonial duplex with hardwood floors and ample natural light that would not have been out of place in California, except of course for the price tag. The elderly landlady lived alone downstairs with her three dogs. The place came totally unfurnished, so we set out on a Saturday to get what we needed to call it home for the coming year.
 This meant, first, hopping on a bus. Quito has a BRT (bus rapid transit) system (and now  a subway under construction), but its three BRT lines are extremely crowded and run along the city's north-south axis, leaving east-west trips more difficult.
  Fortunately there was an enormous amount of informal public transit to be had: big blue buses run by private operators would ply every major avenue, with a bevy of signs—up to a dozen—in the front windshield listing major destinations: neighborhoods, universities, other landmarks. No route map, no advance schedule—but with a little basic geographic knowledge of the city, I found you could reliably hop a bus from anywhere to anywhere for 25 or 50 cents with no more than a 5-minute wait time at the stop.
 Scarcely any U.S. city can compete with Quito—a place I was told would be poor and dysfunctional—in the ease of getting around on public transit. The network of these informal bus lines has not been coordinated from above: it took me an hour of Googling to understand that there  was no master schedule and system map in one place. The system is  chaotic but smart: if there is demand for a trip (in the form of overcrowding on buses between points A and B), someone is going to figure it out and capitalize on it. What this system lacks in legibility—I do enjoy poring over transit route maps online and planning out my trip before I leave home—it gains in rapid, iterative adaptability.
 We went to a part of town comprised of a few blocks heavily populated with furniture stores. Each individual store was quite small and had a limited, idiosyncratic selection. But with a half dozen of them in close proximity, it was easy to wander and comparison shop. Within an hour or so, we had a dining room set we loved, a couple lamps and a couch. A used stove and refrigerator we procured from individual vendors at a vast open-air market where you could buy practically anything. In both cases we insisted they plug the unit in for us and then we came back in an hour to verify that it worked. Haggle over the price, put down a deposit, and it was time to look for transport.
  Transport consisted of two guys with an unmarked truck. A whole street outside the  mercado seemed unofficially devoted to these trucks: just find someone parked and waiting, let them know what they'd be hauling, and pay a little extra if you wanted them to help you get it up the stairs and into the apartment (we did). In a few hours, several hundred dollars poorer, and having experienced an anxiety-inducing ride in the bed of a pickup truck next to a refrigerator secured with ropes, we were home and near-fully furnished.
 We loved the furniture, though the oven soon broke and required tracking down a maintenance man through word of mouth who could get the right replacement parts. Meanwhile, I learned to cook a lot of unlikely things on the stovetop! It was a nice gas stove fueled by a large free-standing tank of propane (which you could get delivered by a truck that made the neighborhood rounds a couple mornings each week).
  The whole experience stands in contrast to my experiences furnishing homes in the United States. Here, the process always involves a drive to a big-box store (few of these are convenient via transit, especially if you need to make multiple stops), a credit check, some paperwork to commit to a multi-month payment plan, a scheduled delivery a week or two out, and often some hassle with the delivery company requiring a phone call in which I sit on hold.
 For that trouble I get a much greater degree of protection against things going wrong. When a dishwasher arrived at my house last year with a large dent already in the side, I was not out any money; they took it away, apologized, refunded me the delivery charge, and allowed me to reschedule for a replacement unit a week later. A few years ago, we bought a couch that, it turned out upon delivery, was impossible to maneuver through a tricky doorway in our backyard ADU (unusually narrow at 29 inches, but also a tight 90° turn). No problem: returned the couch and went to pick out another one.
 You'd think a greater range of choices would be a perk of the U.S. system, but it wasn't for us: the selection at the big boxes was repetitive and heavily influenced by current market trends. There was not a single couch in all of Rooms To Go small enough to make the turn and get through the door into our living room. When I made this observation to the salesperson, she mockingly told me I should consider a bigger house. (True story!) We left and bought a couch from a different big-box store down the road. It was delivered on schedule two weeks later.
  It's clear to me that the way the middle classes do things in the U.S.—the Home Depot / IKEA / Rooms to Go model—has its advantages, especially in reduced risk for the buyer of being scammed and left without recourse. But worth contemplating are the hidden costs of the quality and reliability that these stores promise.
 The biggest such cost is the much higher bar of entry for producer, retailer, and consumer alike. You don't find many small proprietors selling furniture and appliances in the U.S.; it works in cities like Quito because of the physical model of an open-air marketplace with many small retail spaces in close walking proximity to one another. (There are of course now online options for small vendors—Craigslist, Facebook Marketplace, etc.—but that model has its own substantial downsides for something you really want to be able to touch and test out before purchase.) The big-box stranglehold on the market shuts out smaller and artisanal producers, as well. And for the shopper, the price of being a happy consumer without hours of extra hassle, annoying transportation logistics, and uncertainty is often debt, in the form of the car payment and the credit card.
 There was something really, really liberating about the experience of furnishing a home in Quito, as two foreigners with questionable-to-good Spanish, no local bank accounts or locally-accepted credit cards, and fairly unfamiliar with the city. The amount that we were able to get done in a single afternoon was astonishing. The range of options was actually quite good. Getting around was a breeze.
 The U.S. system—the big box store with the vertically integrated supply chain, the warehouse and shipping network, the proprietary credit line—is efficient for one particular group of people: owners of capital. That is to say, executives and shareholders. This model of retail about as effective as could be at extracting profit off the top, by squeezing every bit of redundancy out of each part of the supply chain.
 And the U.S. development pattern, too, plays into that particular model of "efficiency" from the CEO's (or city manager's) vantage point. Separated land uses; giant shopping plazas with giant parking lots; stroads built for 18-wheelers; and transit-only on designated corridors: all of these things  favor the big box model of commerce.
 For everyone else, I think there's a strong argument that we've swung too far in the direction of top-down order and efficiency, and that a swing back toward a messy city and a messy marketplace full of small proprietors—what I've heard called "capitalism with more capitalists"—would yield surprising benefits. I just had to go to South America to see a few of them.

我写的第一篇博文是丢失的，我保存的最古老的一篇是2005年9月8日。已经快15年了，我很高兴看到我在写作和理解世界方面有了很大的进步。
保持这样的网站不仅仅是写照片和选择照片。这需要精心策划和修改东西的组织方式，以确保不会丢失任何东西。
有一件事我不想失去，那就是所有那些来访的令人惊叹的人的评论，他们都花了一些时间来表示赞赏或不同意。最后一个总是学习的好机会，并确保你的信仰仍然是合理和合乎逻辑的。
所以我一头扎进评论数据库，发现有些评论丢失或放错了地方，因为网站的帖子改变了链接。
一些链接被破坏了，不得不拼凑起来；另一些链接是错误的，他们的评论消失了。
我相信我保存了所有的评论，在这个过程中，我走上了一条关于脆弱的回忆和事后诸葛亮的大道，我们建立的网络就是这样的。
还记得Flickr吗？它仍然活着并在运行，但并不是我在2007年认识的每个人都在使用它。你在我以前的帖子中看到的很多照片都来自那里，但是属性链接被破坏了，因为用户决定删除他们的账户。有些人还在工作，但摄影师要么离开了，要么去世了。
由于历史原因，这些链接仍然存在，因为重要的是要表明这些照片有所有者，有才华的人友好地分享他们的作品，而不要求回报。
而且问题并不仅限于“找不到页面”信息中的版权归属问题。就连文件似乎也在恶化。
随着技术的进步，我们有了更好的相机和更好的监视器。原本纯净的照片现在看起来褪色或像素化了。储存也是一个问题。保留一个网站意味着存储所有的文件，对于一个25岁的年轻人来说，预算很小，这意味着节省每一分钱。所以我确保在图像质量和文件大小上保持良好的平衡。它在抵抗时间的考验方面做得并不令人惊叹。
网站有生命周期，我发现的一些链接不再起作用。谷歌和我一样讨厌断开的链接，但我也讨厌对读者不公平。指向不再存在的其他资源的链接仍然存在于我写的文章中。再说一次，为了证明存在的理由。
我知道这个问题已经有一段时间了，因此我养成了保存我用来参考的每个文件的习惯。PDF、视频、图像、音乐等。它们可能不会在文章中使用，因为有指向原始版本或作者的链接，但如果有一天该链接停止工作，其价值不会随之丢失。(这就是为什么这个站点的容量超过9 GB)。
回到过去，和许多网站一样，这个网站是由WordPress提供支持的。它有自己的评论系统。然后碟子1出现了，我试了一会儿。在我停止使用WordPress之后，我继续运行同样的评论服务。这就是所有的链接都改变以提高搜索引擎排名的时候，很多评论在数据库中丢失了。
这份名单可能还会继续，关键是他们已经消失了，一些好的内容也随之而来。
社交网络不一定要消失才能让你无法访问那里的内容。一篇内容的所有者可能会出于各种原因锁定他们的个人资料，您或您的读者将无法再看到它。
对版权侵权的法律行动也可能剥夺对公开信息的访问权。想想看，当YouTube视频被发现违反指导方针时会发生什么。
我们正在犯一些同样的错误。想想有多少社交网络使用URL缩短器。如果bit.ly决定关闭，并且所有这些链接都停止工作，会发生什么情况？
我们正在建设的网站使用WordPress、Drupal等内容管理软件。他们会经受住时间的考验吗？还是我们会在某个时候不得不将他们迁移到一个新的系统？刁钻的问题不会。在那之前，我们可以忠于我们的使命，继续出版。
如果你希望有一个美好的结局，请不要放弃。
通过这些磨难和我们一直在进行的所有实验，我们可以在我们之间进行交流，我们看到了很多好的结果。可能很久没有人注意到的创造者们发现了聚光灯。
社交网络已经找到了或多或少稳定的商业模式，而不会侵犯我们的隐私。以Patreon和Etsy为例。
我们已经建立了一个经济和服务，这些在处理新冠肺炎锁闭事件时是很重要的。
如果我们打击假新闻，我们就能看到关于世界上正在发生的事情的各种重要观点。我们可以联系住在大洋彼岸、碰巧会弹吉他的人类。
我们建立的网络是一个有生命的东西，今天面临着挑战。它发展得太快了，被假新闻和骗局感染了。同时，通过阿拉伯之春和“黑人生命也是命”运动，它帮助我们看到了我们社会的问题所在。
这是由我们来策划和教育的。我们应该努力确保我们在出版时考虑到质量，并采取措施尽可能地让它活下去。我们必须互相教育如何使用网络，如何不成为错误信息和假新闻的受害者。
这是我们能够确保像随机善行这样的社区继续存在的唯一方法，以激励人们了解网络可以变得多么令人惊叹。

The first blog post I wrote was lost, the oldest one I kept is from September 8, 2005. It’s been almost 15 years and I am very happy to see how much better I got in writing and in understanding the world.
 Keeping a site like this is not just about writing and choosing photos. It takes curation and revising how things are organised to make sure nothing gets lost.
 One of the things that I didn’t want to lose were the comments from all the amazing people that have stopped by and given some of their time to show appreciation or disagreement. The last one is always a good opportunity to learn and make sure your beliefs are still sound and logic.
 So I dove into the database of comments, finding some of them lost and misplaced because the website’s posts changed links.
 Some of the links were broken and had to be pieced together; others were wrong and their comments gone.
 I believed I saved all of the comments and in the process drove down an avenue of memories and hindsight on fragile the web we built is.
  Remember flickr ? It’s still alive and running but not everyone I knew back in 2007 still uses it. A lot of the photos you see in my old posts come from there, but the attribution link is broken because the user decided to delete their account. Some are still working, but the photographer moved on, or passed away.
 Those links are still here for historical reasons, and because it is important to show that those photos have owners, talented people that were kind to share their work without asking for return.
 And the problem doesn’t stop at the attributions of copyright that land in a “Page Not Found” message. Even the files seem to deteriorate.
 As technology evolved, we got better cameras and better monitors. Photos that were pristine now look faded or pixelated. Storage was also a problem. Keeping a website means storing all the files and for a 25 year old with a small budget that meant saving every cent. So I made sure to keep a good balance in image quality and file size. It didn’t do an amazing job resisting the test of time.
  Websites have a life cycle, and some of the links I found no longer work. Google hates broken links as much as I do, but I also hate to be unjust to the reader. Links that point to other resources, that no longer exist, are still present in the articles I wrote. Again, for the reason of proof of existence.
 I have known of this problem for a while now, and for that reason I got into the habit of saving every file that I use for reference. PDFs, videos, images, music, etc. They may not be used in the article, because there is a link to the original version or author, but if one day that link stops working, the value won’t be lost with it. (This is why this site amounts to over 9 GB)
  Back in the day, like many, this site was powered by WordPress. It had it’s own comment system. Then disqus  1 appeared, and I tried it for a while. After I stopped using WordPress, I kept the same comment service running. This was when all the links changed to improve the Search Engine Rankings, and a lot of comments got lost in the database.
    The list could go on, the point is that they have disappeared and some good content along with them.
 And a social network doesn’t have to vanish for you to lose access to what’s there. The owner of a piece of content may lock their profile for any number of reasons and you or your readers won’t be able to see it ever again.
 Legal action on copyright infringement can also take away access to something that was public. Just think about what happens when a YouTube video is found to be at fault with the guidelines.
  And we are making some of the same mistakes. Think about how many Social Networks use URL shorteners. What happens if Bit.ly decides to close and all those links stop working?
 The websites that we are building use content management software like WordPress, Drupal and others. Will they withstand the test of time or will we have to migrate them to a new system at some point? Trick question, it won’t. Until then we can stay true to our mission and keep on publishing.
 If you were hoping for a bright ending, please don’t give up just now.
  Through these ordeals and all the experiments we have been running in the way we can communicate among ourselves, we saw a lot of good come out of it. Creators that could have gone unnoticed for ages found a spotlight.
 Social Networks have found business models that are more or less stable without infringing on our privacy. Take  Patreon and  Etsy as an example.
 We have built an economy and services that were important when dealing with the covid-19 lock down.
 And if we fight fake news, we are able to see a variety of important perspectives about what is going on in the world. We can connect with a Human who lives across the ocean and who happens to play guitar.
 The web we built is a living thing and is faced with challenges today. It grew too fast, got infected by fake news and scams. In the meantime, it helped us see what is wrong in our society through the Arab Spring and the Black Lives Matter movements.
 It’s up to us to curate and educate. We should try to make sure that we publish with quality in mind and take steps to see it live on as much as possible. And we have to educate each other on how to use the web and how not to be a victim of misinformation and fake news.
 That’s the only way that we can make sure that communities like  Random Acts of Kindness stay alive to serve as inspiration on how amazing the web can be.
